semantic_identifier: 3908353 - Inland Crest Packaging - sales_pitch - Discussion with Jerry Dean

hierarchy.meeting_title: 3908353 - Inland Crest Packaging - sales_pitch - Discussion with Jerry Dean

sections.text: Arjun Mehta: Hi Jerry—Arjun Mehta here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I work with product and go-to-market teams on getting really crisp about who their best customers are and where to focus next. How are things at Inland Crest Packaging?
Jerry Dean: Hey Arjun. Doing well, thanks. Busy as always. What can I help with?

Arjun Mehta: I’ll be quick. I’m calling because a lot of packaging and manufacturing-adjacent teams hit the same wall: you have a decent spread of customers, but it’s hard to say—based on data—which segments are truly your “best fit,” and which ones look good in pipeline but end up high-support or churn-risk. Does that resonate at all?
Jerry Dean: Yeah, it does. We’ve got a mix—some customers are great, some are a grind. We’re trying to be more intentional about who we target.

Arjun Mehta: Exactly. The product is called Customer_Analyzer. It’s a SaaS tool that pulls in signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding surveys, product usage, support tickets, even interview notes—and turns that into a fit score per account and segment, plus very practical positioning recommendations.
Jerry Dean: Fit score how? Like a lead score?

Arjun Mehta: Similar idea, but it’s grounded in outcomes, not just activity. The core feature is fit_estimation: it computes a 0–100 customer-product fit score at the account level and then rolls that up by segment—say SMB vs mid-market, or by industry, or by use case. You define fit drivers—things like firmographics, problem severity, willingness to pay, time-to-value, adoption patterns, support burden, and churn-risk signals. Then it shows you two key things: the score, and a driver breakdown of why the score is high or low.
Jerry Dean: Okay. We do some of that manually in spreadsheets. It’s… not great.

Arjun Mehta: That’s usually how it starts. Spreadsheets, a few gut-feel categories, and it’s hard to keep current. With Customer_Analyzer, you can answer questions like: “Which segment converts fastest and renews most reliably?” and “Which segment is consuming support capacity but not expanding?”—and you can see it backed by the signals you’re already collecting.
Jerry Dean: What would you need from us to do that? We have CRM data, and we have support tickets in a separate system.

Arjun Mehta: That’s perfect. Typically we start with CRM fields—industry, size, deal size, sales cycle length—plus any onboarding or implementation milestones you track. Then we layer in support burden signals: ticket volume, categories, time-to-resolution, escalations. If you have product usage events, great, but it’s not required on day one. The idea is to quickly get a first pass fit model, then refine.
Jerry Dean: And the output is basically “go after these customers”?

Arjun Mehta: That’s one output. But where teams get the most value is using it for product planning. If you’re deciding where to place roadmap bets, you can identify the high-fit customers who still have unmet needs—so you’re not just building for the loudest accounts, you’re building for the accounts most likely to renew and expand.
Jerry Dean: That’s interesting. We’re in planning right now, actually. We’re debating two or three directions and it’s a lot of opinion.

Arjun Mehta: That’s a great time to do this. In practice, the workflow is: we generate the fit scores and segment comparisons, then you look at “high fit, high retention/expansion” segments versus “low fit, high support” segments. You can make a call like, “Let’s prioritize features that remove friction for the high-fit segment,” or, “Let’s stop chasing a segment that looks big but consistently under-adopts.”
Jerry Dean: How long does it take to get something usable? I don’t want a six-month data project.

Arjun Mehta: Totally fair. The goal is a fast first insight. If you can give us access to a CRM export and a support ticket export, we can usually turn around an initial fit scoring and driver breakdown in a couple of weeks. Then the next step is a review session where we validate whether the drivers match what your team knows—and adjust.
Jerry Dean: And the driver breakdown—what does that look like?

Arjun Mehta: Think of it like: this account scored 82 because it’s in your target industry, reached time-to-value quickly, shows strong adoption signals, and has low support burden; whereas another account scored 41 because time-to-value is long, usage is sporadic, support tickets are high, and expansion historically doesn’t happen in that segment. It makes the “why” explicit, so Sales, Product, and Marketing can align instead of debating anecdotes.
Jerry Dean: That alignment part would help. Sales says one thing, support says another, and product is in the middle.

Arjun Mehta: Exactly. Fit scoring gives you a shared language. Then, separately, we generate positioning recommendations—value props, differentiators, proof points, and objection handling—based on what’s actually working with the highest-fit segments. So when you do target a segment, the messaging is consistent with the reality of what those customers care about.
Jerry Dean: Got it. But for now you’re thinking start with fit scoring and segment analysis?

Arjun Mehta: Yes. For Inland Crest Packaging, I’d suggest we focus on two things in the first pass: (1) account and segment-level fit scores with a driver breakdown, and (2) using that specifically for product planning—identifying high-fit customers with unmet needs to guide your roadmap bets. If we get those right, the rest becomes much easier.
Jerry Dean: What would you need from me to evaluate whether this is worth it?

Arjun Mehta: Great question. I’d propose a 45-minute working session next week with you and whoever owns product planning—could be a product leader or ops—where we map your current segments and agree on 6–10 fit drivers that matter for your business. After that, we can do a lightweight data pull and come back with a sample fit model and a segment comparison.
Jerry Dean: I can do that. I’d probably pull in our product manager for the planning piece. Next week is okay.
Arjun Mehta: Perfect. Before we schedule, two quick checks so I don’t waste your time: First, do you have a clear definition today of your “best customer,” or is it still a bit fuzzy?
Jerry Dean: It’s fuzzy. We have a couple hypotheses, but they’re not validated.
Arjun Mehta: Second, are you seeing meaningful differences in support load or retention across customer types?
Jerry Dean: Yes. Certain customers open a ton of tickets and never really expand. Others barely need us and buy more.

Arjun Mehta: That’s exactly the pattern Customer_Analyzer is designed to quantify. If we can turn that into a clear ICP recommendation and show the segment comparisons, you’ll have something actionable for both targeting and roadmap prioritization.
Jerry Dean: Sounds promising. What days are you thinking?

Arjun Mehta: I have Tuesday at 11 a.m. or Thursday at 2 p.m. your time. We’ll keep it tight: 10 minutes on your current segments, 20 minutes on fit drivers and available data, 15 minutes on what a good output would look like for your roadmap discussion.
Jerry Dean: Thursday at 2 works better. Send an invite and I’ll add our product manager.

Arjun Mehta: Will do. I’ll send a calendar invite for Thursday at 2, plus a short checklist of the data exports that are helpful—CRM fields and a support ticket snapshot. No heavy lift before the call; even a sample export is fine.
Jerry Dean: Okay. Send it over and we’ll take a look.

Arjun Mehta: Great, Jerry. Appreciate the time today. I’ll get that invite out in the next few minutes, and we’ll use Thursday to see if the fit scoring and driver breakdown can give you clearer direction for planning.
Jerry Dean: Sounds good. Talk Thursday.
